user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_dev_dma_unmap:
```c
static void metal_linux_dev_dma_unmap(struct metal_bus *bus,
				      struct metal_device *device,
				      uint32_t dir,
				      struct metal_sg *sg,
				      int nents)
{
	struct linux_device *ldev = to_linux_device(device);
	struct linux_bus *lbus = to_linux_bus(bus);

	ldev->ldrv->dev_dma_unmap(lbus, ldev, dir, sg,
				       nents);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_linux_dev_dma_unmap:
static struct linux_device *to_linux_device(struct metal_device *device)
{
	return metal_container_of(device, struct linux_device, device);
}
...
static struct linux_bus *to_linux_bus(struct metal_bus *bus)
{
	return metal_container_of(bus, struct linux_bus, bus);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The remaining code uses standard C features only: function declarations/definitions, pointer dereferencing, structure member access, standard fixed-width integer type (uint32_t), and a regular function-pointer call. There are no visible inline assembly blocks, GCC/clang-specific attributes, statement expressions, typeof usages, nested functions, zero-length arrays, or other compiler-specific language extensions in the shown fragments (other than the two metal_container_of invocations, which are flagged for inspection because container_of-style macros commonly rely on compiler extensions). Therefore no other fragments need investigation for Rule 1.2 based on the provided code.
